headline: Eby congratulates Carney, then reiterates B.C. demands of Ottawa | Vancouver Sun
context: VICTORIA — On the morning after the election, Premier David Eby, of course, congratulated Prime Minister Mark Carney on the win.

“My call to him remains the same as it was before we knew who the prime minister would be,” Eby said on Tuesday morning. “Now is the time for Canadians to ensure we’re working together to do a couple of things.”

annotations.paragraph: After thanking Jagmeet Singh – and delivering an on-the-spot “no” to seeking the national leadership of the NDP – Eby got on with airing B.C.’s agenda for working together with the new national government.
annotations.reason: The paragraph provides relevant information about Eby's actions and intentions following the election.

annotations.paragraph: As a first order of business, Eby suggested it was a “critical priority” to get rid of interprovincial trade barriers.
annotations.reason: This paragraph is relevant as it outlines a specific priority Eby has for working with the national government.

annotations.paragraph: “It should be as easy to do business with Ontarians as it is currently to do business with Washington state,” said the premier.
annotations.reason: The quote highlights Eby's stance on interprovincial trade, relevant to B.C.'s demands of Ottawa.

annotations.paragraph: The B.C. premier has already endorsed Carney’s deadline of July 1 for a free trade agreement among the provinces. “That is 100 per cent achievable from the B.C. perspective,” he said.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides specific information about Eby's support for a free trade agreement, relevant to the main topic.

annotations.paragraph: B.C.’s version of the enabling legislation to lower interprovincial trade barriers is already making its way through the provincial legislature.
annotations.reason: This provides context on legislative actions related to B.C.'s demands, relevant to the article's focus.

annotations.paragraph: “It doesn’t require other provinces to recognize B.C.,” said the premier. “It allows us to go unilaterally and recognize other provinces’ standards and we are willing to be part of a group of provinces to do that.”
annotations.reason: The quote explains B.C.'s approach to trade barriers, directly related to the demands of Ottawa.

annotations.paragraph: The premier ticked off other items on the to-do list. Support for the softwood lumber industry. Diversification of trade markets. Expedited development of natural resources.
annotations.reason: This lists specific demands and priorities of B.C., relevant to the article's focus on Eby's demands of Ottawa.

annotations.paragraph: Then he got round to a persistent theme of his time in office, a call for Ottawa to treat B.C. fairly when dispensing programs and projects.
annotations.reason: This paragraph introduces Eby's ongoing demand for fair treatment from Ottawa, which is central to the article's premise.

annotations.paragraph: He’s looking to the 43 MPs elected Monday – 20 Liberals, 19 Conservatives, three New Democrats and one Green – to back him up.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides specific details about the MPs Eby is relying on, which is relevant to his demands.

annotations.paragraph: “I’m hopeful that the MPs from B.C. are going to assist our provincial government in ensuring that the federal government meets the baseline expectation that I have for them, that all British Columbians have for them,” said Eby.
annotations.reason: This quote from Eby directly relates to his expectations from the MPs, supporting the article's main theme.

annotations.paragraph: “If they have a federal program in Quebec, in Ontario, that we get access to the same program in B.C, funded to the same level on a population basis. We’re not asking for more. We’re not asking for less, just asking for the same.”
annotations.reason: This quote elaborates on Eby's demand for equal treatment, which is central to the article's focus.

annotations.paragraph: Eby seldom passes up an opportunity to beat the drum on fair treatment. Early in the federal election campaign, he was asked about speculation that Carney would follow the lead of the 1990s Liberals and cut transfer payments to provinces.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides context on Eby's consistent advocacy for fair treatment, relevant to the article's theme.

annotations.paragraph: “I probably won’t lie awake around that,” said the premier. “B.C. already sees a reduction in the amount of money we get from the federal government.”
annotations.reason: The paragraph provides direct commentary from Premier Eby about B.C.'s financial relationship with the federal government.

annotations.paragraph: He also complained about equalization payments — formula-based payments designed to help poorer provinces match the services of richer provinces.
annotations.reason: The paragraph introduces the topic of equalization payments, which is relevant to B.C.'s demands of Ottawa.

annotations.paragraph: “Quebec gets $13 billion annually in transfers. Ontario got $1 billion. Manitoba gets $5 billion. We get nothing, and Alberta gets nothing, and Saskatchewan gets nothing.”
annotations.reason: The paragraph provides specific figures on equalization payments, highlighting the disparity that B.C. is concerned about.

annotations.paragraph: “What I would hope that Mr. Carney does is look at all federal transfer payments and ensure that they’re basically fair across the country, that you see the same per capita distribution, that it is comprehensible to people why one province gets more than another.
annotations.reason: The paragraph outlines Eby's expectations for Carney regarding federal transfer payments, directly related to B.C.'s demands.

annotations.paragraph: “Right now it is incomprehensible – unless you look at it through the lens of the number of seats that are available to the governing party,” he added. “That is a crass thing to say, but that is the reality that I see.”
annotations.reason: The paragraph provides Eby's critical perspective on the political motivations behind federal transfer payments.

annotations.paragraph: The premier was back at it late in the campaign when Preston Manning, the former leader of the Reform party, invoked the threat of Western separatism.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides context about a political issue relevant to Eby's demands.

annotations.paragraph: “People like Preston Manning are seeking clicks and playing to a political base that is completely disavowed by the vast majority of Canadians,” said Eby. “It is a tired trope, an attack on the unity that we have right now as a country standing up to the Trump administration. I hate it. It is awful. I want them to stop.”
annotations.reason: This paragraph contains a direct quote from Eby addressing a political issue related to his demands.

annotations.paragraph: But having discounted Manning’s complaint, he seized the opening to air his own list of grievances.
annotations.reason: This paragraph transitions to Eby's specific grievances, relevant to the article's focus.

annotations.paragraph: “There are special programs for Ontario and Quebec that are not delivered to other provinces, and when that happens it gives these opportunists the chance to get on Facebook and say, yeah, let’s separate from the rest of Canada. It’s nonsense, but it feeds that fire,” said the premier.
annotations.reason: This paragraph contains a direct quote from Eby detailing specific grievances, relevant to the article's focus.

annotations.paragraph: “So my advice to the prime minister would be to do the basic fairness things. It’s not profoundly difficult, but it will address, I think, a significant source of the fuel that these guys are using to drive an argument that is a dead end.”
annotations.reason: This paragraph contains Eby's advice to the prime minister, directly related to the article's focus.

annotations.paragraph: But not such a dead end that it doesn’t serve a political purpose or two.
